Decentralized Aggregation for Energy-Efficient Federated Learning via Overlapped Clustering and D2D Communications

Mohammed S. Al-Abiad, Member, IEEE, Mohanad Obeed, Md. Jahangir Hossain, Senior Member, IEEE, and Anas Chaaban, Senior Member, IEEE The authors are with the School of Engineering, the University of British Columbia, Kelowna, BC V1V 1V7, Canada (e-mail: m.saif@alumni.ubc.ca, mohanad.obeed@ubc.ca, jahangir.hossain@ubc.ca, anas.chaaban@ubc.ca).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a distributed machine learning (ML) technique to train models without sharing users‚Äô private data. In this paper, we propose a decentralized FL scheme that is called federated learning empowered overlapped clustering for decentralized aggregation (FL-EOCD). The introduced FL-EOCD leverages device-to-device (D2D) communications and overlapped clustering to enable decentralized aggregation, where a cluster is defined as a coverage zone of a typical device. The devices located on the overlapped clusters are called bridge devices (BDs). In the proposed FL-EOCD scheme, a clustering topology is envisioned where clusters are connected through BDs, so as the aggregated models of each cluster is disseminated to the other clusters in a decentralized manner without the need for a global aggregator or an additional hop of transmission. Unlike the star-based FL, the proposed FL-EOCD scheme involves a large number of local devices by reusing the RRBs in different non-adjacent clusters. To evaluate our proposed FL-EOCD scheme as opposed to baseline FL schemes, we consider minimizing the overall energy-consumption of devices while maintaining the convergence rate of FL subject to its time constraint. To this end, a joint optimization problem, considering scheduling the local devices/BDs to the CHs and computation frequency allocation, is formulated, where an iterative solution to this joint problem is devised. Extensive simulations are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm over FL conventional schemes in terms of energy consumption, latency, and convergence rate.

Index Terms:
Device-to-device (D2D) communications, decentralized and low-latency federated learning, energy consumption, overlapped clustering.

I Introduction

Machine learning (ML) techniques have been leveraged to provide various services, such as virtual reality, traffic prediction, and object recognition [1, 2, 3]. The ML model training is usually implemented at the base station (BS) in a centralized manner, where the raw data is required to be collected at the BS for training coexist. However, in many applications, datasets are generated at edge devices, and consequently, transmitting raw data from all devices to BS incurs huge network traffic and devices data privacy leakage [4]. Therefore, the traditional centralized ML techniques are not preferable for next generation wireless networks [5]. Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising distributed machine learning (ML) algorithms for addressing the aforementioned bandwidth and privacy challenges [6, 7].

I-A Federated Learning at the Network Edge

The popular FL conventional architectures are: (i) star-based FL architecture [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and (ii) relay-assisted/dual-hop FL [14, 15, 16, 17], also called hierarchical FL. In each iteration of the star-based FL, each device trains a local model based on its own dataset and then transmits its local trained model to the BS. The BS then aggregates all the received models into one global model and broadcasts it back to the devices. These procedures are repeated several rounds until the global model converge. Similar to the star-based FL, the hierarchical FL requires the BS to aggregate all the local models of the devices, which are collected by cluster-heads (CHs) (or relays). In particular, two-hop transmission is required in the hierarchical FL, i.e., the CHs/relays need to forward the local models of devices to the BS. Despite the fact that hierarchical FL can improve the limited connectivity of devices and reduce their energy consumption, its main limitation, as previously mentioned, is that it requires two-hop transmission. However, these FL conventional architectures pose prime concerns for the wireless edge since the devices may exhibit: (i) significant heterogeneity in their computational resources (e.g., limited battery and CPU computations) [18]; (ii) varying proximity to the BS (e.g., varying distances from devices to the BS in a cell). As a consequence, a significant amount of energy is consumed to bounce the model between the BS and the devices [8]. This consumes the power of the battery-powered devices and the available resources at the BS that may be used for another set of devices.

Towards energy-efficient FL while offloading the BS for performing global aggregations, we consider a new angle for developing resource-efficient and decentralized FL using device-to-device (D2D) communications [19]. D2D communications has been demonstrated to be a promising technology in 5G and beyond, such as fog computing and IoT systems [20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25]; indeed, it is expected that 50%percent5050\% of all network connections will be machine-to-machine by 2023 [26]. For example, D2D communications has been shown to be promising for significantly improving the energy efficiency, the reliability, and the data rate [20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25]. Unlike the hierarchical FL that can also use D2D clustering, we propose to overlap the clusters such that there is no need to have an additional level of aggregation at the BS, which may consume more energy. Therefore, it is imperative to exploit D2D communications and introduce a novel decentralized FL scheme for tackling the aforementioned issues of the FL conventional schemes.

Recently, a hybrid FL scheme that integrates the star-based topology with D2D communications, called semi-decentralized FL, was designed in [27]. The authors exploited D2D communications to propose a consensus mechanism to mitigate model divergence via low-power communications among nearby devices. However, the main limitation of the semi-decentralized FL in [27] is that it uses a global aggregator and two-time scale FL (i.e., D2D communications and device-to-BS wireless transmissions). Different from the work in [27], we design a novel decentralized FL scheme that clusters devices in a way that the models of each cluster is implicitly shared to the other clusters without the need for additional stage of aggregation at the BS. To this end, we propose a novel decentralized FL and resource allocation D2D paradigm to minimize the overall energy consumption of a delay-constrained FL in a partially connected D2D system. In the envisioned system, each single-antenna device has a limited coverage zone, named cluster, and dynamically works as: (i) a local device; (ii) a bridge device (BD); or (iii) a CH that can aggregate the models of the associated local devices and BD in its cluster.

I-B Related Works and Challenges

Since the devices are battery-driven, for a sustainable operation of an FL framework in latency-sensitive applications, it is crucial to reduce the energy consumption of the edge devices and the FL time that consists of computation and communication latency. Therefore, we will focus on works addressing resource efficiency and latency-constrained FL, which is the main focus of this paper. Specifically, star-based and hierarchical latency-constrained FL schemes will be reviewed in this section and evaluated in the numerical results section. For a comprehensive survey of the FL literature, we refer the reader to e.g., [28].

Several works extensively considered star-based FL from different aspects, such as frequency computation, wireless communications, and radio resource management, e.g., [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]. Another set of works investigated the impact of wireless link conditions, number of collaborating edge devices, and computation frequency allocation on the performance of star-based FL [10, 11, 12, 13]. However, these works mainly relied on the BS for global aggregations. To reduce the demand for global aggregations, a set of works considered a hierarchical system with two-hop transmission, e.g., [14, 15, 16, 17], [29]. For example, the authors in [29] developed a hierarchical FL model where edge servers perform partial global aggregations. As mentioned before, such a hierarchical FL model leads to increasing the energy consumption and delay.

For developing energy-efficient FL, several works considered minimizing communication and computation energy, e.g., [30, 31, 32, 33]. In [30], the authors proposed an energy-efficient radio resource allocation for delay constrained FL, where they minimized the communication energy and ignored the computation energy. In [32], radio resource allocation was developed to minimize both the communication and computation energy in an FL system subject to delay constraints. The authors in [33] proposed joint transmit power and computation frequency allocation to reduce the overall energy consumption of an FL in a fog-aided internet of things (IoT) network. Recently, a joint optimization framework considering device scheduling, transmit power allocation, and device‚Äôs computation frequency allocation was proposed to simultaneously minimize the total energy consumption and maximize the number of the scheduled devices [34]. However, an energy-efficient framework, while jointly considering communication and computation energy, for facilitating FL for network edge devices in partially connected D2D networks was not investigated in the existing literature.

Different from the aforementioned works, our goal is to propose a scheme, called federated learning empowered overlapped clustering for decentralized aggregation (FL-EOCD), that: (i) involves a decentralized FL scheme without a global aggregation at the BS; (ii) incorporates both local model training and CHs‚Äô aggregated models dissemination among the CHs through the BDs; and (iii) develops an innovative clustering method leading to a computationally efficient solution. However, the proposed FL-EOCD scheme exhibits the following two challenges.

  1. 1.

    Challenge I: Unlike the aforementioned FL conventional systems where the optimization is performed only over the device scheduling and computation capability of collaborating devices, the optimization in the considered D2D environment also considers the selection of the set of CHs to achieve the best FL network performance. Therefore, the performance of FL (i.e., accuracy and convergence) jointly depends on the selection of CHs, scheduled devices, RRB resource allocation, and computation frequency allocation of the scheduled devices. Therefore, to fully capitalize the advantage of D2D communications, we must carefully consider a joint optimization of the CHs selection, device and RRB scheduling, and computation frequency allocation of the devices.

  2. 2.

    Challenge II: In practice, there is a trade-off between the FL time (i.e., computation time and wireless transmission latency) and edge device energy consumption; since reducing the FL time requires more energy. However, the computation time of devices is affected by the allocated computing resources, and increasing the computation frequency of the devices can reduce the latency at the cost of the increased energy consumption. Furthermore, the wireless data transmission latency is determined by the wireless transmission rate, which is related to wireless transmission power. To reduce the wireless communication latency, we can increase the transmission power, however this will consume more energy. Accordingly, a joint optimization of the degrees-of-freedom, namely, CHs selection, device scheduling to the CHs/RRBs, and computation frequency allocation, is required to satisfy a given FL time constraint and reduce energy consumption.

I-C Contributions

The specific contributions of this work are summarized as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We introduce a decentralized FL scheme, called FL-EOCD, which augments the conventional star-based and hierarchical FL architectures with overlapped clustering that enables global models dissemination without the need for a central aggregation at the BS. In FL-EOCD, the local models are trained at the devices and transmitted to the scheduled CHs for aggregation. Meanwhile, the BDs exploit their connectivity between the CHs to disseminate the received aggregated models among all the CHs in the network. Different from conventional FL schemes, FL-EOCD scheme clusters devices in a way that the models of each cluster is implicitly shared to the other clusters, where the aggregation is implemented in a distributed manner. To the best of the authors‚Äô knowledge, this is the first work that introduces a decentralized FL scheme to efficiently deal with convergence rate, energy-efficiency, and learning time without involving a BS for aggregations.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We develop an energy-efficient framework to facilitate the introduced FL-EOCD scheme for the energy-limited devices in the partially connected D2D network. We formulate an optimization problem to minimize both the computation and communication energy consumption of the devices subject to constraints on FL time, device connectivity, scheduling among the device-CH/RRB, and computation frequency allocation. The proposed joint optimization problem is NP-hard, and thus the global optimal solution is computationally intractable. To tackle such difficult optimization problem, an iterative solution framework is devised. Specifically, the overall CH selection, device-CH scheduling, and computation frequency allocation problem is decomposed into two sub-problems, namely, CHs selection and their devices scheduling sub-problem and computation frequency allocation sub-problem. For each sub-problem, we propose a solution of polynomial computational complexity, and rigorously justify the effectiveness of the proposed solutions. By iteratively solving these sub-problems, an FL-EOCD algorithm is developed to minimize the energy consumption.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The effectiveness of the proposed FL-EOCD scheme is verified and compared with the existing FL schemes via simulations. Simulation results show that the proposed FL-EOCD scheme achieves 55%percent5555\% (30%percent3030\%) and 35%percent3535\% (50%percent5050\%) lower energy consumption and shorter FL time, respectively, compared to the considered star-based and hierarchical FL schemes. In terms of convergence rate, if the required accuracy is low (e.g., 80%percent8080\%), the proposed scheme requires more global iterations (around 3%percent33\% more) than the star-based and the hierarchical FL schemes. If the required accuracy is high (e.g., >93%absentpercent93>93\%), the proposed, star-based, and hierarchical schemes need the same number of global iterations.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The system model is described in Section¬†II. The optimization problem formulation is provided in Section¬†III. The proposed solution is presented in Section¬†IV. Section¬†V presents an overview of the properties of the FL-EOCD algorithm. The simulation results and the concluding remarks are provided in Section¬†VI and Section¬†VII, respectively.

II System Model and Federated Learning

II-A System Overview

We consider a partially connected D2D network with a single BS and a set of devices that is denoted by ùí©={1,2,‚ãØ,N}ùí©12‚ãØùëÅ\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\}. An example of the envisioned system model is illustrated in Fig. 1. Each device nùëõn has a limited coverage zone that represents the service area of that device within a circle of radius ùöÅùöÅ\mathtt{R}. Such a service area is denoted in this work as a cluster. It is assumed that the clusters are formed based on the ability of devices to conduct low-energy D2D communications, e.g., geographic proximity. Therefore, the set of devices in the nùëõn-th device‚Äôs cluster is defined by ùíún={m‚ààùí©|dn,m‚â§ùöÅ\mathcal{A}_{n}=\{m\in\mathcal{N}|d_{n,m}\leq\mathtt{R}}, where dn,msubscriptùëëùëõùëöd_{n,m} is the distance between the nùëõn-th device and the mùëöm-th device. It is assumed that each device cannot transmit and receive at the same time, i.e., half-duplex D2D channel is adopted, and each device is equipped with a single antenna. Meanwhile, the BS in this work is not engaged in the FL global aggregation model and it is responsible for the scheduling process only. In particular, it decides the CH/BD selection and local device-CH association and delivers the scheduling parameters to the CHs/BDs over reliable control and non-payload communication (CNPC) channels.

The FL model training is considered through a sequence of global iterations indexed by t={1,2,‚ãØ,T}ùë°12‚ãØùëát=\{1,2,\cdots,T\} as it will be explained in the next subsection. In each global iteration, devices have fixed locations and can change their locations in different global iterations [27, 13]. Subsequently, at any FL global iteration, the set of devices ùí©ùí©\mathcal{N} is divided into: i) a subset of devices that can perform local learning on their dataset, this subset of devices are called local devices, ii) a subset of devices that can perform local learning and aggregate the local models of devices in their clusters which are denoted by cluster heads (CHs), and iii) a subset of devices that can perform local learning and combine the received aggregated models from adjacent CHs with their own local models and forward them back to the adjacent CHs for aggregated model disseminations; this subset of devices are called bridge devices (BDs). Let ùí©l={1,2,‚ãØ,Nl}subscriptùí©ùëô12‚ãØsubscriptùëÅùëô\mathcal{N}_{l}=\{1,2,\cdots,N_{l}\} be the subset of local devices; ùíû={1,2,‚ãØ,C}ùíû12‚ãØùê∂\mathcal{C}=\{1,2,\cdots,C\} is the subset of CHs; ‚Ñ¨={1,2,‚ãØ,B}‚Ñ¨12‚ãØùêµ\mathcal{B}=\{1,2,\cdots,B\} is the subset of BDs; where ùí©l‚à™ùíû‚à™‚Ñ¨‚ààùí©subscriptùí©ùëôùíû‚Ñ¨ùí©\mathcal{N}_{l}\cup\mathcal{C}\cup\mathcal{B}\in\mathcal{N}. For simplicity and unless otherwise stated, ùí©lsubscriptùí©ùëô\mathcal{N}_{l} represents the set of scheduled devices and BDs, since the BDs can also perform local learning.

We propose that the local devices and BDs transmit their local models to their assigned CHs via D2D links using orthogonal RRBs in an uplink phase. Specifically, each CH is granted a limited number of ZùëçZ orthogonal RRBs that are denoted by the set ùíµ={1,2,‚ãØ,Z}ùíµ12‚ãØùëç\mathcal{Z}=\{1,2,\cdots,Z\}, where local devices can use them to transmit their trained models to the scheduled CHs. Each RRB is used to denote a time/frequency resource block of each CH, i.e., a group of orthogonal sub-carriers [35, 36]. In this work, we consider that each local device is scheduled to only one RRB, and each RRB is assigned to only one local device. II-B Federated Learning Process

We propose an FL-EOCD scheme that has distinguishing features compared to the conventional FL schemes, e.g., star-based FL models [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and hierarchical FL models [14, 15, 16, 17]. Particularly, our envisioned scheme learns the local models at devices and aggregates a shared global model through CHs and BDs without the need for global aggregations at the BS.

Let ùíünsubscriptùíüùëõ\mathcal{D}_{n} denote the local data set of the nùëõn-th local device, which represents a set of data samples {xi,yi}subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ\{x_{i},y_{i}\}, where xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} is the sample iùëñi‚Äôs input (e.g., image pixels) and yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i} is the sample iùëñi‚Äôs output (e.g., label of the image). Here, ùíün={(xi,yi):i=1,‚ãØ,Dn}subscriptùíüùëõconditional-setsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëñ1‚ãØsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\mathcal{D}_{n}=\{(x_{i},y_{i}):i=1,\cdots,D_{n}\} denotes the dataset involved in the training process of the nùëõn-th local device. The total dataset involved in the training process in the system is ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}. A widely used model in linear regression, logistic regression, and deep neural networks is considered, where the local loss function on the dataset of the nùëõn-th local device can be calculated as

In what follows, we explain the FL process of our advised learning model.

(1) FL process: In the envisioned FL-EOCD process, there are global iterations and local iterations. The specific process of the proposed FL-EOCD at the tùë°t-th global iteration can be summarized as follows, which is presented in Fig. 2.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The BS judiciously determines a subset of local devices ùí©l={1,2,‚ãØ,Nl}subscriptùí©ùëô12‚ãØsubscriptùëÅùëô\mathcal{N}_{l}=\{1,2,\cdots,N_{l}\} to independently train local ML models and subsets of CHs and BDs;

  • ‚Ä¢

    Each CH cùëêc sends its updated aggregated model ùê∞c‚Äã(t‚àí1)subscriptùê∞ùëêùë°1\mathbf{w}_{c}(t-1) to its scheduled devices ùí©lcsubscriptsuperscriptùí©ùëêùëô\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l} and the associated BDs in a downlink phase. Note that adjacent CHs transmit the aggregated models simultaneously using orthogonal RRBs and the CHs of the non-adjacent clusters can transmit their aggregated models to the selected local devices on the same RRB.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Each selected device n‚ààùí©lùëõsubscriptùí©ùëôn\in\mathcal{N}_{l} executes a local update algorithm (e.g., stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm) based on its dataset ùíünsubscriptùíüùëõ\mathcal{D}_{n} and the aggregated model ùê∞c‚Äã(t‚àí1)subscriptùê∞ùëêùë°1\mathbf{w}_{c}(t-1) of its associated CH cùëêc. The output of this local learning at the nùëõn-th device is the updated local model ùê∞c,n‚àó‚Äã(t)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞ùëêùëõùë°\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c,n}(t);

  • ‚Ä¢

    Meanwhile, BDs receive the aggregated models ùê∞c‚Äã(t‚àí1)subscriptùê∞ùëêùë°1\mathbf{w}_{c}(t-1) from the associated CHs ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, perform a local learning algorithm, aggregate the received models and their own updated models, forward the aggregated models to the corresponding CHs at the uplink phase of each iteration. This ensures the dissemination of the aggregated models of the CHs over the entire network. On the other hand, each CH can subtract its previous model from the received aggregated model of the BDs to retrieve the aggregated model of the adjacent CH(s) as will be explained next.

We define the loss function for the cùëêc-th CH as the average local loss across the cùëêc-th cluster,

L^‚Äã(ùê∞)=1‚àën|ùíün|‚Äã‚àën=1Nlc|ùíün|‚ÄãLn‚Äã(ùê∞).^ùêøùê∞1subscriptùëõsubscriptùíüùëõsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëÅùëêùëôùëõ1subscriptùíüùëõsubscriptùêøùëõùê∞\hat{L}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{\sum_{n}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|}\sum^{N^{c}_{l}}_{n=1}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|L_{n}(\mathbf{w}). (2)

The global loss function L‚Äã(ùùé)ùêøùùéL(\boldsymbol{\omega}) is then defined as the average loss across all the clusters,

L‚Äã(ùê∞)=1‚àën|ùíün|‚Äã‚àën=1Nl|ùíün|‚ÄãLn‚Äã(ùê∞).ùêøùê∞1subscriptùëõsubscriptùíüùëõsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëÅùëôùëõ1subscriptùíüùëõsubscriptùêøùëõùê∞L(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{\sum_{n}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|}\sum^{N_{l}}_{n=1}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|L_{n}(\mathbf{w}). (3)

The objective of the FL model training is to find the optimal model parameters ùê∞‚àósuperscriptùê∞\mathbf{w}^{*} for L‚Äã(ùê∞)ùêøùê∞L(\mathbf{w}) that is expressed as follows ùê∞‚àó=arg‚Å°minùê∞‚Å°L‚Äã(ùê∞)superscriptùê∞subscriptùê∞ùêøùê∞\mathbf{w}^{*}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}L(\mathbf{w}). Next, we explain in details the operations that are performed at the CHs and the BDs.

(2) BD and CH aggregation process: For simplicity of the ensuing analysis, we explain the operations that should be implemented at the CHs and BDs through an example. Consider an example of the envisioned FL model that is shown in Fig. 3, where the CHs and their scheduled devices and BDs are given. Suppose that each CH is granted 444 RRBs where local devices can transmit their local models. We first explain the operations of the CHs and BDs based on the overlapped chain clustering as in Fig. 3, then we generalize the operations for any number of clusters and any form of clustering structure. For notations convenience, here, we use cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i} to denote the cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}-th CH, while in the remaining sections we use the notation cùëêc for the cùëêc-th CH.

Iteration 1: The c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}-th, c2subscriptùëê2c_{2}-th, and c3subscriptùëê3c_{3}-th CHs transmit their initial models ùê∞ci‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñ0\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0) to the associated devices. For example, the c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}-th CH transmits its model ùê∞c1‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëê10\mathbf{w}_{c_{1}}(0) to the n1subscriptùëõ1n_{1}-th and n2subscriptùëõ2n_{2}-th devices, and the b1,2subscriptùëè12b_{1,2}-th BD. The c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}-th and c3subscriptùëê3c_{3}-th CHs can broadcast their models on the same RRB, while the c2subscriptùëê2c_{2}-th CH uses different RRB. Accordingly, the b1,2subscriptùëè12b_{1,2}-th and b2,3subscriptùëè23b_{2,3}-th BDs receive the models from the c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}-th and c2subscriptùëê2c_{2}-th CHs and the c2subscriptùëê2c_{2}-th and c3subscriptùëê3c_{3}-th CHs, respectively. Afterword, each device executes the local learning algorithm, whose output is ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(1)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõ1\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(1), i.e., ùê∞1,1‚àó‚Äã(1)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞111\mathbf{w}^{*}_{1,1}(1) represents the local model of the n1subscriptùëõ1n_{1}-th device that is scheduled to the c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}-th CH. While the devices do the local learning, the bi,jsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{i,j}-th BD picks one model from the received ones (i.e., ùê∞ci‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñ0\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0) or ùê∞cj‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëó0\mathbf{w}_{c_{j}}(0)) or both of them after aggregation to update its own model ùê∞di‚Äãj‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëëùëñùëó0\mathbf{w}_{d_{ij}}(0) using its available dataset. Hence, the di,jsubscriptùëëùëñùëód_{i,j}-th BD has now three models which are ùê∞bi,j‚Äã(1)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëèùëñùëó1\mathbf{w}_{b_{i,j}}(1), ùê∞ci‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñ0\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0), and ùê∞cj‚Äã(0)subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëó0\mathbf{w}_{c_{j}}(0). The bi,jsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{i,j}-th BD then aggregates these three models as follows

ùê∞bi,ja‚Äãg(1)=1Dci+Dcj+Dbi,j(Dciùê∞ci(0)+Dcjùê∞cj(0)+Dbi,jùê∞bi,j(1)),superscriptsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëèùëñùëóùëéùëî11subscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëósubscriptùê∑subscriptùëèùëñùëósubscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñ0subscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëósubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëó0subscriptùê∑subscriptùëèùëñùëósubscriptùê∞subscriptùëèùëñùëó1\mathbf{w}_{b_{i,j}}^{ag}(1)=\frac{1}{D_{c_{i}}+D_{c_{j}}+D_{b_{i,j}}}(D_{c_{i}}\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0)+D_{c_{j}}\mathbf{w}_{c_{j}}(0)\\ +D_{b_{i,j}}\mathbf{w}_{b_{i,j}}(1)), (4)

where Dcisubscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëñD_{c_{i}} and Dcjsubscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëóD_{c_{j}} are the total number of data points of the local devices that are associated to the cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}-th and cjsubscriptùëêùëóc_{j}-th clusters, respectively, and Dbi,jsubscriptùê∑subscriptùëèùëñùëóD_{b_{i,j}} is the number of data points at the bi,jsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{i,j}-th BD. At the uplink phase of the first iteration, each local device transmits its updated model, while each BD transmits the aggregated model given in (4).

Iteration 2: Now, each CH has received different models from the associated local devices and BDs. We propose that each CH first aggregates the models of the local devices (without including the models of the BDs) as follows

ùê∞ci‚Äã(1)=1Dci‚Äã‚àën=1NlciDn‚Äãùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(1).subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñ11subscriptùê∑subscriptùëêùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëôsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùê∑ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõ1\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(1)=\frac{1}{D_{c_{i}}}\sum_{n=1}^{N_{l}^{c_{i}}}D_{n}\mathbf{w}_{c_{i},n}^{*}(1). (5)

Then, the cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}-th CH extracts the models of the other clusters aggregated with the BD‚Äôs model from the models received by the BDs. Dc1‚Äãùê∞c1‚Äã(0)+Db1,2‚Äãùê∞b1,2‚Äã(1)=(Dc1+Dc2+Db1,2)‚Äãùê∞b1,2a‚Äãg‚Äã(1)‚àíDc2‚Äãùê∞c2‚Äã(0),subscriptùê∑subscriptùëê1subscriptùê∞subscriptùëê10subscriptùê∑subscriptùëè12subscriptùê∞subscriptùëè121subscriptùê∑subscriptùëê1subscriptùê∑subscriptùëê2subscriptùê∑subscriptùëè12superscriptsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëè12ùëéùëî1subscriptùê∑subscriptùëê2subscriptùê∞subscriptùëê20D_{c_{1}}\mathbf{w}_{c_{1}}(0)+D_{b_{1,2}}\mathbf{w}_{b_{1,2}}(1)=(D_{c_{1}}+D_{c_{2}}+D_{b_{1,2}})\mathbf{w}_{b_{1,2}}^{ag}(1)\\ -D_{c_{2}}\mathbf{w}_{c_{2}}(0), (6)

Each device then can update its local model based on the available dataset and the received model from the associated CH. Whereas, each BD first removes the redundant models that has been received from the previous round, conducts the local learning, sums the aggregated models of the adjacent CHs, and transmits back to the associated CHs. It is important to note that once the model received by a CH or a BD, they first remove the models that they know from the previous iterations.

Iteration 3 and beyond: At the third iteration, we can notice that the model of the c3subscriptùëê3c_{3}-th CH is attained by the c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}-th CH and vise versa but with a delay of two iterations. In the third iteration and in the next ones, each CH first aggregates the models of the associated devices, cleans the models received from the associated BDs by removing the known previous models, aggregates the devices‚Äô model with the models received by the associated BD(s), and then broadcasts back to the associated devices. Whereas, each BD first cleans the received models, conducts local learning to update its own model, aggregates the received models with the updated one, transmits to the associated CHs.

(3) Local learning process: We consider the SGD algorithm to solve the local training problem of devices. Let ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t) denote the local model parameter of the nùëõn-th local device with the associated cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}-th CH at the tùë°t-th global round and the t~~ùë°\tilde{t}-th local iteration. Define ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(t)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t) as the local model parameter of the nùëõn-th local device with the associated cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}-th CH at the tùë°t-th global iteration after the local iterations are converged, which can be expressed as

ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(t)=arg‚Å°minùê∞ci‚Äã‚àáLn‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t)).subscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°subscriptsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñ‚àásubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t)=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}}\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t)). (10)

The local model parameter ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t) in the t~~ùë°\tilde{t}-th local iteration is updated according to the gradient of Ln‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t))subscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°L_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t)) and the learning rate Œ¥ùõø\delta, i.e.,

ùê∞ci,nt~+1‚Äã(t)=ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t)‚àíŒ¥‚Äã‚àáLn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t)),subscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°1subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°subscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°ùõø‚àásubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}+1}_{c_{i},n}(t)=\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t)-\delta\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t)), (11)

where ùê∞ci,n0‚Äã(t)=ùê∞ci‚Äã(t)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞0subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°subscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°\mathbf{w}^{0}_{c_{i},n}(t)=\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t) because it is the initial value and can be obtained from the cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}-th CH. Then, the modified loss function of the nùëõn-th local device at the tùë°t-th global round ‚àáGn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t))‚àásubscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°\nabla G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t)) can be calculated as ‚àáGn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t))=‚àáLn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t))‚àí‚àáLn‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t))+Œ∑‚Äã‚àáL‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t)),‚àásubscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°‚àásubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°‚àásubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°ùúÇ‚àáùêøsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°\nabla G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t))=\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t))-\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t))+\eta\nabla L(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t)), where Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is a positive constant to control the FL convergence rate. Since ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(t)subscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t) is the converged local model parameter, we have

‚àáGn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(t))=‚àásubscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°absent\displaystyle\nabla G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t))= ‚àáLn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(t))‚àí‚àáLn‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t))‚àásubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°‚àásubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°\displaystyle\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t))-\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t))
+Œ∑‚Äã‚àáL‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t))=0.ùúÇ‚àáùêøsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°0\displaystyle+\eta\nabla L(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t))=0. (12)

The local iterations are continued until the local model accuracy œµlsubscriptitalic-œµùëô\epsilon_{l} is reached, which is defined as Gn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,nt~‚Äã(t))‚àíGn‚Äã(ùê∞ci,n‚àó‚Äã(t))‚â§œµl‚Äã[Gn‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚Äã(t))‚àíGn‚Äã(ùê∞ci‚àó‚Äã(t))]subscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞~ùë°subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°subscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùëõùë°subscriptitalic-œµùëôdelimited-[]subscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°subscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëêùëñùë°G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t))-G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t))\leq\epsilon_{l}[G_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t))-G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i}}(t))]. On the other hand, the global iteration continues until the global model accuracy œµgsubscriptitalic-œµùëî\epsilon_{g} is reached, which is defined as L‚Äã(ùê∞‚Äã(t))‚àíL‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚â§œµg‚Äã[L‚Äã(ùê∞0)‚àíL‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)]ùêøùê∞ùë°ùêøsuperscriptùê∞subscriptitalic-œµùëîdelimited-[]ùêøsuperscriptùê∞0ùêøsuperscriptùê∞L(\mathbf{w}(t))-L(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq\epsilon_{g}[L(\mathbf{w}^{0})-L(\mathbf{w}^{*})].

III Modeling and Problem Formulation

We consider the energy consumption minimization problem that involves a joint management of computation and communication resources, CH clustering, and device selection problem for the delay-constrained FL. As such, we evaluate the introduced FL scheme from communication and computation perspective. Therefore, first we provide FL time and total energy consumption expressions, and then we formulate the energy consumption minimization problem.

III-A FL Time and Energy Consumption

(1) FL time constraint: At the tùë°t-th global iteration, the FL delay is caused by: (i) the computation time for local model training at the scheduled local devices ùí©lsubscriptùí©ùëô\mathcal{N}_{l}; (ii) the transmission time for transmitting local trained updates to the associated CHs ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}; and (iii) the transmission time for transmitting the clusters aggregated models from the associated CHs to the scheduled devices ùí©lsubscriptùí©ùëô\mathcal{N}_{l}.

The nùëõn-th local device executes a local update algorithm until a local accuracy œµlsubscriptitalic-œµùëô\epsilon_{l} is achieved [37]. Let us denote QnsubscriptùëÑùëõQ_{n} as the number of CPU cycles to process one data sample and fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} is the computational frequency of the CPU in the nùëõn-th local device (in cycles per second). We obtain the number of CPU cycles of the nùëõn-th local device in a one local iteration over its dataset ùíünsubscriptùíüùëõ\mathcal{D}_{n} as Qn‚ÄãDnsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõQ_{n}D_{n} and the computation time for a one local iteration in the nùëõn-th device as Qn‚ÄãDnfnsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõ\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}} [38, 39]. The computation time of the nùëõn-th local device is then expressed as

Tnc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp=Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn,subscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëùùëõsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõT^{comp}_{n}=T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}, (13)

where TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l} is the number of local iterations to reach the local accuracy œµlsubscriptitalic-œµùëô\epsilon_{l} in the nùëõn-th local device. The training parameters of the local devices are considered to have a fixed size [40], and denote sùë†s as parameter data size of the nùëõn-th local device. Therefore, the transmission time of the nùëõn-th local device for uploading its parameters to the cùëêc-th CH on the zùëßz-th RRB is Tnc‚Äão‚Äãm=sRc,znsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõT^{com}_{n}=\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}.

The aggregated model parameters can only be updated by the CHs after all local model parameters are received from the scheduled devices and BDs. Consequently, the FL time is dominated by the longest duration time of receiving the local parameters from all scheduled devices and the longest duration time of aggregated models from the CHs to its scheduled devices. Note that the transmission duration of the cùëêc-th CH to transmit its aggregated parameter with size sùë†s to its scheduled devices ùí©lcsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëôùëê\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c} is Tcc‚Äão‚Äãm=maxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{sRcn}subscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëêsubscriptùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëôùëêùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëõùëêT^{com}_{c}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c}}\left\{\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}\right\}. Hence, the learning time œÑcsubscriptùúèùëê\tau_{c} at the cùëêc-th CH can be calculated as

œÑcsubscriptùúèùëê\displaystyle\tau_{c} =maxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{Tnc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+Tnc‚Äão‚Äãm}+Tcc‚Äão‚Äãmabsentsubscriptùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëôùëêsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëùùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëê\displaystyle=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c}}\{T^{comp}_{n}+T^{com}_{n}\}+T^{com}_{c}
=maxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn+sRc,zn}+maxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{sRcn}.absentsubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùí©ùëêùëôsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõsubscriptùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëôùëêùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëõùëê\displaystyle=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l}}\left\{T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}\right\}+\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c}}\left\{\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}\right\}. (14)

Therefore, for each global iteration, the total learning time œÑ=maxc‚ààùíû‚Å°(œÑc)ùúèsubscriptùëêùíûsubscriptùúèùëê\tau=\max_{c\in\mathcal{C}}(\tau_{c}), which should be no more than the QoS requirement (i.e., œÑùúè\tau should be no more than the maximum federated learning time TmaxsubscriptùëámaxT_{\text{max}}). Typically, this constraint, over all global iterations TùëáT, is expressed as

T‚Äã{maxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn+sRc,zn}+maxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{sRcn}}‚â§Tmax,ùëásubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùí©ùëêùëôsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõsubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùí©ùëêùëôùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëõùëêsubscriptùëámax\displaystyle T\left\{\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l}}\left\{T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}\right\}+\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l}}\left\{\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}\right\}\right\}\leq T_{\text{max}}, (15)

(2) Energy consumption: The total energy consumption of our considered system is caused by the following:

  • ‚Ä¢

    The energy that is consumed due to local computation at the local devices, where the energy consumption of the nùëõn-th local device to process a single CPU cycle is Œ±‚Äãfn2ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëõ\alpha f^{2}_{n}, and Œ±ùõº\alpha is a constant related to the switched capacitance [39, 41].   • ‚Ä¢

    The energy consumption to transmit local model parameters to the associated CHs can be denoted by Enc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëõE^{com}_{n} and calculated as pn‚ÄãTnc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptùëùùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëõp_{n}T^{com}_{n}. Let us denote the total energy consummation at the nùëõn-th local device as En=Enc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+Enc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptùê∏ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëùùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëõE_{n}=E^{comp}_{n}+E^{com}_{n}. Similarly, the energy consumption to transmit the cùëêc-th CH aggregated model to the associated local devices is denoted by Ecc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëêE^{com}_{c} and calculated as pc‚ÄãTcc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptùëùùëêsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëêp_{c}T^{com}_{c}.

Therefore, the total energy consumption of our envisioned system can be calculated as

Eùê∏\displaystyle E =T‚Äã{‚àën‚ààùí©lEn+‚àëc‚ààùíûEcc‚Äão‚Äãm}absentùëásubscriptùëõsubscriptùí©ùëôsubscriptùê∏ùëõsubscriptùëêùíûsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëê\displaystyle=T\left\{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}}E_{n}+\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}E^{com}_{c}\right\}

(16)

III-B Problem Formulation

We consider the following two binary optimization variables: (i) sn,csubscriptùë†ùëõùëês_{n,c} for device-CH scheduling; and (ii) rc,znsubscriptsuperscriptùëüùëõùëêùëßr^{n}_{c,z} for device-RRB assignment. In addition, we consider the computation frequency allocation vector fN=[fn]subscriptfNdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëõ\textbf{f}_{\text{N}}=[f_{n}]. The energy consumption minimization optimization problem is formulated as

P0:‚Äãminsn,c‚àà{0,1},rc,zn‚àà{0,1},fN,ùíû‚ààùí´‚Äã(ùí©)‚Å°EP0:subscriptformulae-sequencesubscriptùë†ùëõùëê01subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëõùëêùëß01subscriptfùëÅùíûùí´ùí©ùê∏\displaystyle\text{P0:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}s_{n,c}\in\{0,1\},r^{n}_{c,z}\in\{0,1\},\\ \textbf{f}_{N},\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N})\end{subarray}}E
s.t.{C1:‚Äã‚àëc‚ààùíûsc,n=1&‚àëz‚ààùíµrc,zn=1,‚àÄn‚ààùí©l,C2:‚Äã‚Ñ¨c‚à©‚Ñ¨c‚Ä≤=1,‚àÄ(c,c‚Ä≤)‚ààùíû,C3:‚Äãfnmin‚â§fn‚â§fnmax,‚àÄn‚ààùí©l,C4:‚ÄãœÑ‚â§Tmax,formulae-sequencestcasesformulae-sequenceC1:subscriptcùíûsubscriptscn1subscriptzùíµsubscriptsuperscriptrncz1for-allnsubscriptùí©lotherwiseformulae-sequenceC2:superscript‚Ñ¨csuperscript‚Ñ¨superscriptc‚Ä≤1for-allcsuperscriptc‚Ä≤ùíûotherwiseformulae-sequenceC3:subscriptsuperscriptfnsubscriptfnsubscriptsuperscriptfnfor-allnsubscriptùí©lotherwiseC4:ùúèsubscriptTmaxotherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1:}\hskip 5.69046pt\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}s_{c,n}=1~{}\&~{}\sum_{z\in\mathcal{Z}}r^{n}_{c,z}=1,\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C2:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathcal{B}^{c}\cap\mathcal{B}^{c^{\prime}}=1,\forall(c,c^{\prime})\in\mathcal{C},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C3:}\hskip 5.69046ptf^{\min}_{n}\leq f_{n}\leq f^{\max}_{n},~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C4:}\hskip 5.69046pt\tau\leq T_{\text{max}},\\ \end{cases}

In P0, C1 indicates that each local device is assigned to only one CH and to only one RRB in that CH; C2 indicates that at maximum one BD can be assigned to two adjacent CHs at the same time. In practice and due to the nature of D2D communications, we can have more than one BD at the overlap regions of adjacent CHs. In this case, the BD in the middle of overlapped regions is selected and other BDs are scheduled to the most suitable CHs. C3 is the constraint on local computation resource allocation of devices; and C4 indicates the QoS requirement on the FL time.

To simplify C4 and using (15), we have T‚Äãmaxn‚ààùí©lc‚Å°{Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn+sRc,zn+sRcn}‚â§Tmaxùëásubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùí©ùëêùëôsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëõùëêsubscriptùëámaxT\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l}}\left\{T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}+\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}\right\}\leq T_{\text{max}} which can be transformed into T‚Äã(Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn+sRc,zn+sRcn)‚â§Tmax,‚àÄn‚ààùí©lc,c‚ààùíûformulae-sequenceùëásubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëõùëêsubscriptùëámaxformulae-sequencefor-allùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùí©ùëêùëôùëêùíûT\left(T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}+\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}\right)\leq T_{\text{max}},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l},c\in\mathcal{C}. IV Proposed Solution

IV-A Proposed Solution Approach

Problem P1 is a mixed-integer non-linear programming problem as it involves a joint optimization of the continuous computation frequency allocation and discrete resource assignment variables (e.g., CH-devices/BD and RRB scheduling). In addition, the selection of CHs ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} and their scheduled local devices/BDs are inter-dependent and should be considered jointly. We can readily show that P1 is an NP-hard problem. Even if we fix one of these variables, P1 still remains NP-hard. An exhaustive search is required to obtain the global optimal solution of problem P1, which is infeasible in practical systems. To overcome the aforementioned computational intractability, an iterative approach is devised, where we decompose P1 into two sub-problems. Particularly, considering that fn‚àó‚Äã‚àÄn‚ààùí©lsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõfor-allùëõsubscriptùí©ùëôf^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l} are given, the energy consumption can be obtained from the following optimization problem.

P2:‚Äãminsn,c‚àà{0,1},rc,zn‚àà{0,1},ùíû‚ààùí´‚Äã(ùí©)‚Å°E‚Äãs.t.C1,C2,‚ÄãC4.formulae-sequenceP2:subscriptformulae-sequencesubscriptùë†ùëõùëê01subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëõùëêùëß01ùíûùí´ùí©ùê∏stC1C2,C4\displaystyle\text{P2:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}s_{n,c}\in\{0,1\},r^{n}_{c,z}\in\{0,1\},\\ \mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N})\end{subarray}}E~{}~{}\rm s.t.\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1},\text{C2,}~{}\text{C4}. (19)

While for the given CH clustering and device-CH/RRB scheduling, the computation frequency allocation of the local devices are obtained by solving the following sub-problem

P3:‚ÄãminfN‚Å°E‚Äãs.t.C3,C4.formulae-sequenceP3:subscriptsubscriptfùëÅùê∏stC3C4\displaystyle\text{P3:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\textbf{f}_{N}\end{subarray}}E~{}~{}\rm s.t.\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C3},\text{C4}. (20)

A suitable solution to P1 is obtained by iteratively solving the sub-problems P2 and P3. The sub-problems P2 and P3 are solved in Section¬†IV-C and Section¬†IV-D, respectively, and the overall algorithm to solve P1 is provided in Section¬†V-A.

IV-B CH, BD, and Local Device Scheduling: P2 Reformulation

It is recalled that the set of CHs is ùíû‚ààùí´‚Äã(ùí©)ùíûùí´ùí©\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N}). Let Œ∫c‚Äã(ùíû)subscriptùúÖùëêùíû\kappa_{c}(\mathcal{C}) be the set of scheduled local devices that are associated to CH c‚ààùíûùëêùíûc\in\mathcal{C}. Note that Œ∫c‚Äã(ùíû)subscriptùúÖùëêùíû\kappa_{c}(\mathcal{C}) is a function of the set of CHs ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}. However, for convenience, the set will be dropped unless it is required, e.g., we will use Œ∫csubscriptùúÖùëê\kappa_{c} instead of Œ∫c‚Äã(ùíû)subscriptùúÖùëêùíû\kappa_{c}(\mathcal{C}).

P2 considers a joint optimization of both CHs selection and their scheduled devices and BDs, denoted by ùíû‚ààùí´‚Äã(ùí©)ùíûùí´ùí©\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N}), ùí©lsubscriptùí©ùëô\mathcal{N}_{l}, and ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B}, respectively. In particular, P2 involves inner and outer optimization problems: the inner one optimizes the device/BD scheduling to reduce the network utility function while the outer one aims at finding the most suitable CHs. Therefore, the joint inner and outer optimization sub-problem P2, for a given fn‚àó‚Äã‚àÄn‚ààùí©lsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõfor-allùëõsubscriptùí©ùëôf^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}, can be given at the top of the next page.

Unfortunately, the outer optimization problem (21) and the inner optimization problem (22) of P2.1 are inter-dependent and should be solved jointly. Solving P2.1 optimally using an exhaustive search is intractable [42, 43]. In this work, we develop a tractable graph theoretical and clustering method that carefully selects the number of clusters, their corresponding CHs, and scheduled local devices/BDs. As such, it achieves an effective solution to the optimization problem P2.1.

IV-C CH Clustering and Local Device/BD Scheduling: Solution to P2.1

(1) Graph representation: We first design a conflict graph that considers the restrictions in device-CH/RRB scheduling and the partial connectivity of the CHs. In this context, a conflict graph is constructed for each device cùëêc in the network and denoted by ùí¢c‚Äã(ùí±c,‚Ñ∞c)subscriptùí¢ùëêsubscriptùí±ùëêsubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{G}_{c}(\mathcal{V}_{c},\mathcal{E}_{c}) wherein ùí±csubscriptùí±ùëê\mathcal{V}_{c} and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} are the set of vertices and edges, respectively. Since each device cùëêc can schedule local devices in its coverage zone ùíúcsubscriptùíúùëê\mathcal{A}_{c} only, a vertex vc,nz‚ààùí±csubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëêùëõsubscriptùí±ùëêv^{z}_{c,n}\in\mathcal{V}_{c} is generated for each local device n‚ààùíúcùëõsubscriptùíúùëên\in\mathcal{A}_{c} and for each RRB zùëßz. In the conflict graph, two distinct vertices vc,nzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëêùëõv^{z}_{c,n} and vc,n‚Ä≤z‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëêsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤v^{z^{\prime}}_{c,n^{\prime}} are adjacent by a scheduling conflict edge if one of the following cases occurs:

  • ‚Ä¢

    CC1: The same local device is associated with both vertices vc,nzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëêùëõv^{z}_{c,n} and vc,n‚Ä≤z‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëêsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤v^{z^{\prime}}_{c,n^{\prime}}, i.e., n=n‚Ä≤ùëõsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤n=n^{\prime}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    CC2: The same RRB is associated with both vertices vc,nzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëêùëõv^{z}_{c,n} and vc,n‚Ä≤z‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëêsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤v^{z^{\prime}}_{c,n^{\prime}}, i.e., z=z‚Ä≤ùëßsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤z=z^{\prime} and n‚â†n‚Ä≤ùëõsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤n\neq n^{\prime}.

Recall that each selected CH is granted a limited number of ZùëçZ RRBs. Thus, each CH can schedule at maximum ZùëçZ local devices, and the maximum of ZùëçZ vertices can be represented by the minimum-weight independent set (MWIS) in the conflict graph. In what follows, we transform problem (22) into a MWIS problem. First, we present the following remarks about the MWIS.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Any independent set (IS) Œ∫csubscriptùúÖùëê\kappa_{c} in the conflict graph ùí¢csubscriptùí¢ùëê\mathcal{G}_{c} must satisfy: i) Œ∫c‚äÜùí¢csubscriptùúÖùëêsubscriptùí¢ùëê\kappa_{c}\subseteq\mathcal{G}_{c}; ii) ‚àÄv,v‚Ä≤‚ààŒ∫cfor-allùë£superscriptùë£‚Ä≤subscriptùúÖùëê\forall v,v^{\prime}\in\kappa_{c}, where (v,v‚Ä≤)‚àâ‚Ñ∞cùë£superscriptùë£‚Ä≤subscript‚Ñ∞ùëê(v,v^{\prime})\notin\mathcal{E}_{c}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    A minimal IS in an undirected graph cannot be expanded to add one more vertex without affecting the pairwise non-adjacent vertices.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The IS Œ∫csubscriptùúÖùëê\kappa_{c} is referred to an MWIS of ùí¢csubscriptùí¢c\mathcal{G}_{\text{c}} if it satisfies: i) Œ∫csubscriptùúÖùëê\kappa_{c} is an IS in graph ùí¢csubscriptùí¢c\mathcal{G}_{\text{c}}; ii) the sum weights of the vertices in Œ∫csubscriptùúÖùëê\kappa_{c} offers the minimum among all ISs of ùí¢csubscriptùí¢c\mathcal{G}_{\text{c}}. Therefore, the MWIS will be denoted as Œ∫c‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëê\kappa^{*}_{c}.

Given ùí¢csubscriptùí¢ùëê\mathcal{G}_{c}, the optimization problem (22) for a fixed fn‚àó‚Äã‚àÄn‚ààùí©lsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõfor-allùëõsubscriptùí©ùëôf^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l} is similar to MWIS problems. In MWIS problems, two vertices must be non-adjacent in the conflict graph, which is similar to problem (22), where two local devices cannot be allocated with the same RRB. Likewise, the same RRB cannot be allocated to two different local devices. Furthermore, the objective of (22) is to minimize the energy consumption, while the goal of MWIS is to select a set of vertices with minimum weights. Hence, the following corollary characterizes the solution of the optimization problem (22).

Corollary 1.

The solution Œ∫c‚àó‚Äã(ùíû)subscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëêùíû\kappa^{*}_{c}(\mathcal{C}) of the optimization problem (22) for device cùëêc is the MWIS Œ∫c‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëê\kappa^{*}_{c} in the conflict graph ùí¢csubscriptùí¢ùëê\mathcal{G}_{c} of device cùëêc in which the weight of each vertex vc,nzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëêùëõv^{z}_{c,n} is w‚Äã(vc,nz)=Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn‚àó+sRc,znùë§subscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëêùëõsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõw(v^{z}_{c,n})=T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}.

(2) CH Clustering: Essentially, two adjacent clusters are formed, and accordingly, their corresponding CHs can simultaneously transmit the aggregated models to the scheduled local devices if the CHs‚Äô coverage zones are overlapped by at least one BD. This is to ensure that the shared BD can exchange the received aggregated models to the adjacent CHs.

We construct the whole set of clusters ùêÖùêÖ\mathbf{F} such that: (i) all coverage zones of adjacent clusters F‚ààùêÖùêπùêÖF\in\mathbf{F} are pairwise overlapped by one BD; and (ii) within the same cluster FùêπF, each subset of local devices is interfering with at least another local device. Mathematically, the clusters in ùêÖùêÖ\mathbf{F} should satisfy: (i) ùêÖ={F‚ààùí´‚Äã(ùí©)|ùíúc‚à©ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F\c)‚â†‚àÖ,‚àÄc‚ààF}ùêÖconditional-setùêπùí´ùí©formulae-sequencesubscriptùíúùëêsuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°\ùêπùëêfor-allùëêùêπ\mathbf{F}=\{F\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N})~{}|\mathcal{A}_{c}\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F\backslash c)\neq\emptyset,\forall c\in F\}; (ii) ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F)‚à©ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F‚Ä≤)=1,‚àÄ(F,F‚Ä≤)‚ààùêÖformulae-sequencesuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°ùêπsuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°superscriptùêπ‚Ä≤1for-allùêπsuperscriptùêπ‚Ä≤ùêÖ\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F)\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F^{\prime})=1,\forall(F,F^{\prime})\in\mathbf{F}. Therefore, we have the following lemma for the overlapped clustering construction.

Lemma 1.

For any particular set ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, the corresponding overlapped clustering ‚Ñ±‚ààùêÖ‚Ñ±ùêÖ\mathcal{F}\in\mathbf{F} satisfies the following constraints

‚®ÅF‚àà‚Ñ±F=ùíûsubscriptdirect-sumùêπ‚Ñ±ùêπùíû\displaystyle\bigoplus_{F\in\mathcal{F}}F=\mathcal{C} (23a)
ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F)‚à©ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F‚Ä≤)=1,‚àÄF‚â†F‚Ä≤‚àà‚Ñ±,formulae-sequencesuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°ùêπsuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°superscriptùêπ‚Ä≤1for-allùêπsuperscriptùêπ‚Ä≤‚Ñ±\displaystyle\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F)\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F^{\prime})=1,\forall F\neq F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{F}, (23b)
ùíúc‚à©ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F\c)‚â†‚àÖ,‚àÄc‚ààF,formulae-sequencesubscriptùíúùëêsuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°\ùêπùëêfor-allùëêùêπ\displaystyle\mathcal{A}_{c}\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F\backslash c)\neq\emptyset,\forall c\in F, (23c)

where ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F)superscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°ùêπ\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F) is the total coverage zone of all local devices in the cluster FùêπF defined as ùíút‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äã(F)=‚à™c‚ààFùíúcsuperscriptùíúùë°ùëúùë°ùêπsubscriptùëêùêπsubscriptùíúùëê\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F)=\cup_{c\in F}\mathcal{A}_{c}. Thus, for any ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, there exists a clustering ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±\mathcal{F} satisfying the constraints (23a), (23b), and (23c) simultaneously. In (23a), ‚®Ådirect-sum\bigoplus denotes a partition symbol.

Proof.

The proof is analogous to [43, Lemma 1], and is omitted due to the space limitation. ‚àé

It is recalled that local devices can only communicate with their respective neighbors over a wireless D2D link whose connectivity can be characterized by an undirected graph ùí¢‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí±‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) with ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V} denoting the set of vertices and ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} the set of edges. To design a scheduling scheme meeting the aforementioned clustering properties, we construct the graph ùí¢‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí±‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) as follows. We represent a cluster FùêπF by a vertex VùëâV in the graph, and two vertices are connected by a scheduling link if the represented clusters are satisfying (23b). Next, to select the device-CH/RRB scheduling that provides a minimum energy consumption while maximizing the number of scheduled local devices in each cluster and guarantees the FL time constraint, we assign a weight w‚Äã(V)ùë§ùëâw(V) to each vertex V‚ààùí±ùëâùí±V\in\mathcal{V}. For notation simplicity, we define the utility of the nùëõn-th local device as En=Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn‚àó+sRc,znsubscriptùê∏ùëõsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõE_{n}=T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}} and the utility of cluster FùêπF represented by vertex VùëâV as w‚Äã(V)=‚àën‚ààŒ∫c‚àóEn+Ecc‚Äão‚Äãmùë§ùëâsubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëêsubscriptùê∏ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëêw(V)=\sum_{n\in\kappa^{*}_{c}}E_{n}+E^{com}_{c}. Therefore, the following theorem characterizes the solution to the energy consumption minimization problem P2.1, for a given fn‚àó‚Äã‚àÄn‚ààùí©lsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõfor-allùëõsubscriptùí©ùëôf^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}, in a partially connected D2D network.

Theorem 1.

The solution to the energy consumption minimization problem P2.1 in the partially connected D2D network is equivalent to the weighting-search method, in which the weight of each vertex VùëâV representing cluster FùêπF is

w‚Äã(V)=‚àën‚ààŒ∫c‚àóEn+Ecc‚Äão‚Äãm,ùë§ùëâsubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëêsubscriptùê∏ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëê\displaystyle w(V)=\sum_{n\in\kappa^{*}_{c}}E_{n}+E^{com}_{c}, (24)

where Œ∫c‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëê\kappa^{*}_{c} is the MWIS problem in the conflict graph of CH kùëòk for device scheduling

Œ∫c‚àó=arg‚Å°minŒ∫c‚ààùí¢c‚Å°(‚àën‚ààŒ∫c(Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDnfn‚àó+sRc,zn)).subscriptsuperscriptùúÖùëêsubscriptsubscriptùúÖùëêsubscriptùí¢ùëêsubscriptùëõsubscriptùúÖùëêsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëêùëßùëõ\displaystyle\kappa^{*}_{c}=\arg\min_{\mathtt{\kappa}_{c}\in\mathcal{G}_{c}}\left(\sum_{n\in\kappa_{c}}\left(T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}\right)\right). (25)

Essentially, any possible solution to P2.1 using Theorem 1, representing CHs selection and their scheduled local devices, satisfies the following criteria: (i) the represented local devices by vertices in the conflict graph are scheduled to the best CHs/RRBs such that they transmit their local parameters quickly; (ii) the represented CH in each vertex is selected, so as it has a good reachability to many local devices in its coverage as well as it is overlapped with the neighboring CHs. This does not only increase the number of selected local devices that can participate in the training process, but also minimizes the number of clusters; and (iii) a vertex (representing by a subset of local devices) with a smaller weight (representing a sum of their consumed energy) will have a higher priority to be selected in participating in the training process to minimize the objective of P2.1.

The overall steps of cluster generation, conflict graph construction, and MWIS selection to obtain the CH clustering and device scheduling over the scheduled RRBs are summarized in Algorithm 1.
